Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Hyunseung Kang is "Causal Inference Using Instrumental Variables with Possibly Invalid Instruments." The host institution for the fellowship is Stanford University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Guido Imbens.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hyunseung Kang was funded under a two-year postdoctoral fellowship exploring the theory and methods when invalid instruments are present in an instrumental variables analysis. Instrumental variables is a widely used method in economics, statistics, epidemiology, health and social sciences to estimate and infer causal effects of a treatment on an outcome of interest using variables called instruments. These instruments must satisfy core assumptions, including (A1) association to the treatment, (A2) no direct effect on the outcome conditional on the treatment, and (A3) no association to unmeasured confounders that confoudn the treatment-outcome relationships. Instruments that satisfy assumptions (A1)-(A3) are commonly referred to as valid instruments.

Beacuse valid instruments are hard to find in practice, one often has invalid instruments to determine causal effects. The work resulting from the postdoctoral fellowship explored the theoretical limits of estimating causal effects with imperfect, invalid instruments, and proposed methodos that are robust to presence of invalid instruments. The work established theoretical limits that suggests that effect estimation is possible if multiple valid instruments are available, without knowing which ones are valid a priori, and presented ways to screen out valid instruments from invalid instrument among a set of candidate instruments. The work also developed software in R that implemented these robust methods as well as a video tutorial on using the software for wider use.
